thread.title: 8 cool things to do in Huntsville this weekend (and beyond)
thread.title_full: 8 cool things to do in Huntsville this weekend (and beyond) | AL.com

author: Matt Wake | mwake@al.com
title: 8 cool things to do in Huntsville this weekend (and beyond)
text:
The Lowry House Horror Flickfest
7:30 p.m. Oct. 8
The Historic Lowry House, 1205 Kildare St. N.W.
$3
Wes Craven's 1984 "A Nightmare on Elm Street" launched the long-running horror franchise by having razor-fingered baddie Freddy Krueger slash attractive young actors, including Johnny Depp. The film kicks off a month long Thursday horror fest at The Historic Lowry House, a home built in the 1800s. Other titles set for the series include director Ed Wood's 1959 notorious "Plan 9 from Outer Space" (Oct. 15) and 2001's Jake Gyllenhaal-starring "Donnie Darko" (Oct. 22). Each outdoor screening opens with a classic silent or local horror short. More info at facebook.com/lowryhouse .
Hannah Aldridge. (Courtesy photo)
 Hannah Aldridge, David Mayfield and Walt Aldridge
7 p.m. Oct. 8
Tangled String Studios, located at Lowe Mill, address 2211 Seminole Drive
$25 advance, $30 day of, paypal.com
Sultry-voiced Nashville-via-Muscle Shoals singer Hannah Aldridge 's 2014 album "Razor Wire" ranges from murder ballad "Strands of Pearls" to a cover of Jason Isbell's song "Try," backed by Isbell's band The 400 Unit. David Mayfield 's "Good Man Down" LP features guest spots from Seth Avett and Dierks Bentley. Hannah's father Walt Aldridge has penned hits for Travis Tritt ("Modern Day Bonnie and Clyde"), Ronnie Milsap ("(There's) No Gettin' Over Me") and Heartland ("I Loved Her First").
Miranda Lambert
8 p.m. Oct. 8
Von Braun Center, 700 Monroe St.
$36.75 - $56.75 plus applicable fees
Following her recent split with fellow country star Blake Shelton, spitfire Miranda Lambert's probably giving her shows just a little more oomph right now. Lambert brings her feisty hits ("Kerosene," "Little Red Wagon," "Famous in a Small town," etc.) and "Roadside Bars and Pink Guitars" tour to the Rocket City. Make sure to get there early enough to catch talented opener Clare Dunn's set.
Fragments: Guided Exhibition Tour with David Nuttall
5 – 6 p.m. Oct. 10
First Floor Main Gallery, Lowe Mil
Free
Huntsville-based artist David Nuttall walks you through his series of intriguing, fictional maps. Sign up by clicking here or calling 256-682-3919.
The Old Town Walking Tour
10 a.m. Oct. 10
Tour meets at 122 Walker Ave.
Free
Hear the stories behind the Huntsville's most historic neighborhoods. No reservations required but in case of rainy weather call 256-551-2370 to confirm tour is still on.
Kim Richey (w/Logan & Sarah)
7:30 p.m. Oct. 10
Folk Mission, Straight to Ale, 3200 Leeman Ferry Road S.W.
$10 - $20, eventbrite.com
Ohio-born singer/songwriter Kim Richey's music has appeared in TV shows ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer") and movies ("For Love of the Game"). Richey also co-wrote Trisha Yearwood's hit "Believe Me Baby (I Lied)" and sang backing vocals on Ryan Adams' excellent 2000 debut album "Heartbreaker."
Rocket City Lit Fest
10 a.m. – 7 p.m. Oct. 10, 10 a.m. – 6 p.m. 11
Von Braun Center
$8 daily, ages 12 and under free
Authors set to appear including Homer Hickam ("Rocket Boys"), Jenny Lawson ("Let's Pretend This Never Happened") and Les Johnson ("Rescue Mode"). More info at rocketcitylitfest.com .
'Walking Dead' Season 6 Premiere Viewing Party
6 p.m. Oct. 11
Rocket Republic Brewing Company
289 Production Ave., Madison
Free
Zombies are even creepier when they're 15 feet tall. Madison brewery Rocket Republic is showing AMC's cable TV phenomenon "The Walking Dead," based on Robert Kirkman's zombie comic books of the same name, on a 15-foot projection screen. (Broadcast begins at 8 p.m.) "Walking Dead" themed libations are also part the plan.
